intro: Veronica pasquorum, commonly known as the pasque flower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe. It belongs to the Plantain family (Plantaginaceae) and is characterized by its striking, violet-blue flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are hairy and arranged in a basal rosette. Its flowers are arranged in a loose spike and are pollinated primarily by bees and other insects. Veronica pasquorum is well adapted to cold climates and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky soils.
